{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3502261,"name":"","username":"Icros","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/919ad9/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-04T22:32:59.120Z","cooked":"

I’ll lead off with saying that I’m completely new to FRC this year and I’ve never used PathPlanner before, so I may be missing something fundamental.
However, I’ve been trying to set it up to follow a simple path with two waypoints, and I’m getting a trajectory with speed values that oscillate all over the place - see the blue line of requested speed. This happens both on the actual robot and in the simulator.

Screenshot 2025-02-01 at 9.59.08 AM1920×1155 149 KB

This did not happen with similar code with the 2024 PathPlanner in December. I opened an issue with PathPlannerTrajectory generates jittery speeds for simple paths · Issue #1049 · mjansen4857/pathplanner · GitHub, but since no one commented yet, I’m concerned that I’m doing something wrong and this isn’t actually a bug?

As a potential fix, I was attempting to change pathplanner/pathplannerlib/src/main/java/com/pathplanner/lib/trajectory/PathPlannerTrajectory.java at main · mjansen4857/pathplanner · GitHub to take the absolute value, which seemed to smooth out the oscillation, but I’m not sure if this is valid or not.

If I’m reading that graph correctly, you’re only logging left side position/velocity and overall pose. I assume if you graohed the right side as well, youd end up with graphs 180° out of phase. In the real world, this would present as oscillation around the rotation axis (i.e. the angular heading from a gyro). Do you have a gyro? Which one/how is it connected?

Yes, I have a gyro (NavX connected via mxp), but the path I’m trying to follow is just to go straight for 6m. It does seem to be (more or less) doing that, it’s not turning, but it’s constantly speeding up and slowing down.
The right side position/velocity isn’t out of phase, it’s basically identical to this graph, that’s why I didn’t display it.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-02-04T23:14:08.858Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":44,"readers_count":43,"score":23.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485212,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-2025-generates-jittery-speeds","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72154,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-2025-generates-jittery-speeds/485212/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503566,"name":"","username":"Icros","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/919ad9/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T00:03:29.510Z","cooked":"

I discovered that this is only a problem for differential drives, as far as I can tell. If my robot config is:

    RobotConfig differentialConfig = new RobotConfig(74.088, 6.883,
        new ModuleConfig(0.048, 5.45, 1.2, DCMotor.getKrakenX60(1).withReduction(5.143), 60, 2),
        0.56);

then I will get oscillating velocity.
However, if I pretend to have a swerve drive, with:

    RobotConfig holonomicConfig = new RobotConfig(74.088, 6.883,
        new ModuleConfig(0.048, 5.45, 1.2, DCMotor.getKrakenX60(1).withReduction(5.143), 60, 4),
        new Translation2d(0.273, 0.273),
        new Translation2d(0.273, -0.273),
        new Translation2d(-0.273, 0.273),
        new Translation2d(-0.273, -0.273));

then the problem does not occur.
